feed.title: Combined summary - V3 transaction policy for anti-pinning

entry.title: Combined summary - V3 transaction policy for anti-pinning
entry.summary:
In the ongoing discourse on Bitcoin's transaction handling, developers and researchers are grappling with various challenges and potential improvements related to unspent transaction outputs (UTXOs), smart contracts, and the Lightning Network (LN). The management of UTXOs for future fees in smart contracts is complex, with scaling fees alongside the contract's sats-at-risk needing careful consideration due to fingerprinting risks and the insights gained from deploying version 3 (V3) of certain protocols.
Proposals regarding descendant sizes for transactions have been made, suggesting a range from 200 vB for V3 up to 1600 vB for V10 versions. This allows flexibility based on use cases and takes into account historical LN data that suggests past honest transactions have not been widely attacked, making it challenging to pinpoint an optimal value. Node operators are advised to align the maximum value of pending Hash Time-Locked Contracts (HTLCs) with the on-chain fees they are willing to pay.
Research on V3 rules has prompted a reassessment of maximum child size for V3 transactions to potentially reduce costs related to Child Pays for Parent (CPFP) transactions. This impacts the trade-off between utility and pinning costs in LN wallets. Discreet Log Contracts (DLCs) face challenges with fee fluctuations, which are addressed by packaging refund transactions with CPFP transactions, as detailed in the [DLC specifications](https://github.com/discreetlogcontracts/dlcspecs/blob/9cd9148938c616690c79d99ec6f330e213c246c5/Transactions.md#refund-transaction).
Discussions also cover V3 transaction protocol designs, opting into V3 for efficiency, and the search for alternatives to CPFP carveout for security and anti-pinning features. Despite no consensus on the best approach for anchors in LN transactions, the need for a secure anchor type is agreed upon, with a "5x max" fee multiplier suggested in a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) to adapt to varying mempool conditions.
The conversation extends to issues with HTLCs, where making them non-pinnable would require significant alterations. Instead, existing frameworks are used with the intent for future improvements. Fee margin analysis reveals that attackers might only need to pay 25% less than a victim's fee, revealing vulnerabilities that necessitate continuous security updates. Cycle attacks and mitigation strategies like persistent rebroadcasting of transactions are discussed, along with concerns over out-of-band payments to miners increasing centralization and susceptibility to pinning attacks.
Batched CPFP and ephemeral anchors are considered, focusing on efficiency and resistance to pinning attacks. Technical inquiries explore mempool pinning risks with multiple unconfirmed ancestors and potential countermeasures.
The blockchain technology development debate underscores the importance of endogenous fees in smart contracts for maintaining decentralization. Solutions for issues with HTLCs are proposed, such as pre-signing multiple commitment transaction fee variants to accommodate different fees, while ephemeral anchors emerge as a novel approach to maintain decentralization using CPFP-based protocols.
Furthermore, discussions touch on the necessity of incorporating endogenous fees within smart contracts to preserve decentralization, with SIGHASH_ANYONECANPAY presenting risks mitigated by future solutions like SIGHASH_ANYPREVOUT. The impact of presigned HTLC-X transactions on network autonomy is debated, emphasizing the balance between cost-efficiency and decentralized principles.
Lastly, modifying consensus rules for fair and decentralized transaction validation is considered, linking parent ephemeral anchors' inclusion in a block to the corresponding child spend. Insights from Peter Todd about potential consequences of stuckless payments on the Lightning Network's fee structure suggest a need for lower-latency commitment schemes and address vulnerabilities in broadcasting commitment transactions. The community engages in technical discussions, notably on Bitcoin Core Pull Request at [PR28948](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28948issuecomment-1873490509), to evaluate protocol changes aimed at enhancing network efficiency and functionality.
